2011, all executions in Maryland had been stayed until the proper administrative regulations were adopted.[SENTMARKER]On August 16, 2012 this case was administratively closed.[SENTMARKER]In May 2013 pegasus_output_sents: This report is the first report on the progress of the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) in meeting the requirements of the Final Settlement Agreement (FSA) entered in Michelle H., et al v. McMaster and Susan Alford.[SENTMARKER]The FSA reflects DSS’s agreement to address long-standing problems experienced by children in foster care custody and in the operation of South Carolina’s child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]It includes a broad range of provisions governing: caseworker caseloads; visits between children in Foster Care and their caseworkers and family members; investigations of allegations of abuse and neglect; appropriate and timely foster care and therapeutic placements; and access to physical and mental health care for children in DSS custody.[SENTMARKER]The report has been prepared by court-appointed independent Co-Monitors Paul Vincent and Judith Meltzer, with assistance from monitoring staff Rachel Paletta, Elissa Gelber, Gayle Samuels and Erika Feinman, and is presented to The Honorable Richard M Gergel, U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.

gold_sents: A paraplegic individual who uses a wheelchair sued Chipotle for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and California state law in two of its California restaurants.[SENTMARKER]The defendant implemented a new "Customers with Disabilities" which the district court found to be in compliance with the ADA, but the Ninth Circuit found otherwise, that viewing the ingredients behind the counter was part of the "Chipotle Experience."[SENTMARKER]Ultimately, the defendant lowered the heights of the walls in front of the food-preparation areas in all of its California locations so that customers in wheelchairs could see the ingredients, and the plaintiff was awarded $898,549 in attorneys' fees and costs and $5,000 in statutory damages.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2006, a wheelchair-bound customer sued Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc. in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California, alleging that the company violated the Americans with Disabilities Act and the California Disabled Persons Act by denying him full and equal access to two Chipotle restaurants.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted partial summary judgment in favor of Chipotle.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit reversed and remanded the case for a determination of the proper scope of injunctive relief and damages.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The plaintiff, a paraplegic who uses a wheelchair for mobility, sued Chipotle in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff claimed that the high walls between the food and the customers violated the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in part and denied in part the plaintiff's request for attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit overturned the district court's award of $148,000 in attorneys' fees, holding that the award was excessive because no reasonable client would pay such a high fee for such small recovery.

pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 1999, two individuals with disabilities filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against the City of Steamboat Springs, Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the city had discriminated against them on the basis of disability in connection with the provision of transit service and certain other City services, in violation of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Rehabilitation Act).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, monetary damages, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in a consent decree in December 2000 between the plaintiffs and the city.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the city to provide accessible parking spaces on the east side of the city's Howelsen Hill complex, provide training to all bus and van operators, dispatchers, and mechanics, and record the times of the dispatch of alternate transportation.

gold_sents: On December 2, 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (“Amtrak”) for allegedly violating the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12131-12165, by failing to make its intercity rail stations accessible to individuals with disabilities by July 26, 2020, as required by the Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was never properly docketed or assigned to a judge, however, because the government announced its settlement with Amtrak on the same day.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required Amtrak to design at least 135 accessible stations, complete construction at 90 stations, and be in the process of constructing at least 45 stations within 10 years of the settlement date.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required Amtrak to train staff on ADA compliance, establish a monitor-approved process for managing ADA complaints, and create a settlement fund to compensate individuals who were harmed by Amtrak’s most inaccessible stations.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was monitored by the Federal Railroad Administration and the Department of Justice.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 2, 2018, a group of Staten Island students with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the New York City Department of Education, the City, and the City's Chancellor of Education.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DOE funds and operates a wholly separate citywide school district based solely on disability known as District 75, which on Staten Island draws students from Staten Island public schools.[SENTMARKER]According to the plaintiffs' complaint, District 75 students are segregated from their peers in community schools and having few, if any, opportunities to return to a community school.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the plaintiffs allege that the district is violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504), the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), and NYC Human Rights Law (NYCHRL) by failing to educate them in the most integrated setting appropriate or have increased their risk of being subjected to such harms in the future.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final declaratory and injunctive relief order, requiring the DOE to develop and implement a remedial plan that includes new practices, policies, and procedures to ensure that all students in the Plaintiff Class have the opportunity to be educated in an integrated settingappropriate to their needs.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On January 2, 2002, a group of individuals with disabilities filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT) and Millcreek Township, Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act ("ADA") and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 ("Section 504").[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree and partial settlement agreement on November 21, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would resolve potential claims and issues raised by the plaintiffs regarding the accessibility of shoulders and bus stops in Millcreek.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay plaintiffs' reasonable attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed to provide the plaintiffs with a "good faith effort" to subcontract a portion of the project work to a certified Disadvantaged Business Enterprises ("DBEs"), which would be required to provide services, programs or activities in compliance with the terms of the agreement.

gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.

gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 31, 2018, the NAACP and its state and local units filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights (OCR) alleging that the OCR's March 2018 Case Processing Manual (CPM) violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (APA) by requiring mandatory dismissal of certain complaints and eliminating the right of complainants to appeal determinations by OCR to the Enforcement Office Director.[SENTMARKER]On September 28, 2018, and again on November 5, the parties reported that they were engaged in productive settlement negotiations and requested a stay of all deadlines until November 19, 2018 to continue to work to resolve the case.[SENTMARKER]On November 19, 2018, the parties notified the Court that settlement discussions had broken down when Defendants informed Plaintiffs' counsel that they would be no longer willing to offer any stipulation or to settle the matter.[SENTMARKER]The next day, Plaintiffs sought leave to file an amended complaint and a Motion for a Preliminary Injunction to add allegations that Defendants were also using section 108(k) of the March 2018 Manual to dismiss complaints on the basis that a similar complaint filed by another individual had been previously dismissed pursuant to section108(t) and that a citywide moratorium on police chokeholds did not moot an otherwise valid claim for injunctive relief because the moratorium was not permanent.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted Plaintiffs' motion to dismiss, and the parties agreed to provide Plaintiffs with an update on the status of the directed investigations pursuant to paragraphs 2 and 3 of the amended complaint.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 31, 2018, the National Federation of the Blind (NFB) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Education (DOE) and the Office for Civil Rights (OCR).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DOE and OCR violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by mandating the handling and processing of complaints of illegal discrimination made to OCR for investigation.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, plaintiffs challenged the automatic dismissal of any complaint if it is part of "a pattern" of complaints by an individual complainant against multiple recipients, contained in section 108(t) of the OCR Manual; and the right of complainants to appeal determinations by OCR to the Enforcement Office Director.[SENTMARKER]On March 5, 2018, the DOE issued a revised manual, the March 2018 Manual, which superseded the 2015 Manual and contained new provisions requiring mandatory dismissal of certain complaints and elimination of the right to appeal OCR's determinations.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

(COPAA) and Girls for Gender Equity (GGE) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights (OCR).[SENTMARKER]COPAA and GGE are nonprofit organizations whose mission is to educate, support, and provide a variety of services to and advocacy on behalf of students who have experienced sexual harassment and assault.[SENTMARKER]According to one report, 68% of survivors struggle to focus in class.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that OCR violated Title IX when it failed to conclude the investigation of a complaint that a student had been raped while walking home from school, assess the potential danger to the community raised by the complaint, and take action as necessary to ensure the community’s safety and provide appropriate support services to Student B as she struggled to continue her education.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 6, 2020, two organizations filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland, alleging that the Department of Education's (ED) new Title IX regulations violate Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 and the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs allege that the new regulations significantly reduce the agency's responsibility to respond to complaints of sexual harassment and assault, creating an arbitrary and wholly unexplained disparity between its treatment of sex discrimination on one hand, and race, national origin, and disability discrimination on the other.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that the agency has not adequately explained how it reduces the number of sexual assaults that institutions are required to investigate, only because they include some off-campus conduct, is consistent with Title IX.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 8, 2006, a collection of interest groups and individuals, including the Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, Integration and Immigration Rights, and Fight for Equality By Any Means Necessary, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the provisions of Proposal 2 affecting public colleges and universities violated the United States Constitution and federal statutory law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the Attorney General's Motion for Summary Judgment and dismissed the Complaint on its merits.[SENTMARKER]In its March 18, 2008 Opinion and Order, however, the District Court denied the Universities' Motion to Dismiss for misjoinder.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted summary judgment to Michigan, thus upholding Proposal 2.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved a statewide ballot initiative which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]On December 29, 2006, the Sixth Circuit issued an opinion granting Eric Russell’s motion for a stay of this Court’s preliminary injunction pending appeal pending appeal Id.[SENTMARKER]at *15.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that such elections prevented African Americans from being the majority voting bloc in many districts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that this election system unfairly discriminated against African American voters and violated the Federal Voting Rights Act and the 13th, 14th, and 15th amendments.[SENTMARKER]The case is not about the constitutionality, or the merits, of race-conscious policies in higher education.[SENTMARKER]It is about who may resolve it.[SENTMARKER]Democracy does not presume that some subjects are either too divisive or too profound for public debate.

gold_sents: On September 29, 2011, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC") brought this lawsuit against Beverage Distributors Company, LLC ("BDC") on behalf of a visually impaired company employee in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 ("ADA").[SENTMARKER]The EEOC claimed that BDC discriminated against the employee in violation of the ADA when it conditioned his employment on the results of a medical exam and subsequently refused to hire him as a night warehouse loader upon learning that he had a disability.[SENTMARKER]The jury initially awarded the employee $132,347 in back pay, but it found that his damages should be reduced by $102,803 because he could have mitigated those damages by finding a comparable position.[SENTMARKER]On December 9, 2013, the District Court vacated these findings and awarded injunctive relief, only to be reversed by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit because of erroneous jury instructions.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit denied the EEOC's petition for rehearing in May 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in December 2015, and the matter appears to be closed.

gold_sents: Financial advisors who sued their employer, Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., for race and gender discrimination in compensation did not state a plausible claim, so their complaint was dismissed pursuant to Title VII Section 703(h), which allows employers to compensate employees differently on the basis of seniority, merit, or quality or quantity of production.[SENTMARKER]The differences in compensation are only unlawful when they result from an intention to discriminate because of race, color, religion, sex or national origin.

gold_sents: On August 28, 2017, six transgender individuals currently serving in the United States military filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland Maryland contesting the President's ban on transgender service in the U.S. military.[SENTMARKER]Judge Garbis initially granted a motion for a preliminary injunction in September, but this was later stayed in 2019 when the Supreme Court issued a stay of this nationwide injunction in two factually similar cases contesting the ban.[SENTMARKER]This case changed dramatically in 2018 when the government altered its policy on transgender service in the military, eliminating an outright ban and instead putting new guidance on transgender men and women entering the service.[SENTMARKER]Judge Russell, reassigned to the case in 2018, dissolved the preliminary injunction, saying that it was only meant to stay a complete ban on transgender service in the military.[SENTMARKER]This also dismissed all claims against the 2017 outright ban as moot, and removed all plaintiffs that were already in the service and not seeking to join.[SENTMARKER]Discovery is ongoing in the case.

Trump, 926 F.3d 1180, 1206 (9th Cir.)[SENTMARKER](ECF No. 247).[SENTMARKER]The parties and amici have raised a number of other issues which are arguably before us, but we decline to reach them in favor of further proceedings in the court leading to the trial of Plaintiffs’ contentions.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On August 28, 2017, the American Civil Liberties Union of Maryland (ACLU of Maryland) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Department of Defense (D.C.) and the President of the United States (President Trump) challenging the President's ban on transgender individuals serving in the military.[SENTMARKER]On November 21, 2017, the Court issued a preliminary injunction prohibiting the Defendants from taking any action to enforce the policies and directives encompassed in President Trump's August 25, 2017 Memorandum.[SENTMARKER]On January 22, 2019, the Supreme Court stayed the preliminary injunctions issued in this case and in Stockman.[SENTMARKER]On September 14, 2018, the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted Plaintiffs' Motion for a Judicial Determination of Privilege Claims and dismissed Plaintiffs' motion for a judicial determination of privilege claims.

pegasus_output_sents: On November 18, 2009, the U.S. Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant, First United Security Bank, charged African-American borrowers higher rates than similarly-situated white borrowers on home mortgage-related loans.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into an amended settlement agreement on May 7, 2014.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the amended agreement, the defendant agreed to pay a total of $1 million to African-Americans and to implement policies and procedures to ensure that the pricing of its residential loan products is done in a nondiscriminatory manner, consistent with the requirements of the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed to implement an equal housing opportunity slogan, "Equal Opportunity Lender," and all of the Bank's print advertising and promotional materials shall contain a "Equal Housing Opportunity" slogan, or statement.

gold_sents: This case resulted in the largest residential fair lending settlement in U.S. history, with $335 million being paid to compensate African-American and Hispanic borrowers who were allegedly charged more based on their race or national origin.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On December 21, 2011, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against Countrywide Financial Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Countrywide discriminated against African-American and Hispanic borrowers by steering them into subprime mortgages when non-Hispanic white borrowers with similar credit profiles received prime loans.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, Countrywide's business practice allowed its loan officers and mortgage brokers to vary a loan's interest rate and other fees from the price it set based on the borrower's objective credit-related factors.[SENTMARKER]This subjective and unguided pricing discretion resulted in African American and Hispanic borrower paying more.

Spatt granted defendant County's motion for summary judgment dismissing all claims against it.[SENTMARKER]On April 22, 2014, Judge Spatt issued a final order for the plaintiffs and ordered Defendant Garden City to take a number of steps to prevent discrimination and to increase access to affordable housing.[SENTMARKER]After Judge Spatt's order, both parties appealed the decision.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit affirmed in part and remanded in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is back in the lower courts on remand.[SENTMARKER]On remand, Judge Spatt found that the plaintiffs had met their burden at trial in demonstrating that the Garden City’s proffered reasons for its chosen zoning change could have been met by another practice, such as R-M zoning, that had a less discriminatory effect.[SENTMARKER]Magistrate Judge Arlene R. pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2005, MHANY Management, Inc., a non-profit community-based developer of affordable housing incorporated in New York, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the Village of Garden City, the Village Board of Trustees, and the County of Nassau.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by re-zoneing approximately twenty-five acres of County-owned land in Garden City to prevent affordable housing from being built, which would likely be occupied by minorities.[SENTMARKER]On February 12, 2012, the Court granted summary judgment to the County, and dismissed the case against the County.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2010, the district court granted NYCC permission to intervene in the Action as practical successor to ACORN.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2016, the Second Circuit affirmed, in part, and remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the County agreed to create mixed-income affordable housing in "high opportunity" communities within the County and to promote sustainable integrated living patterns, increase fair and equal access to educational, economic and other opportunities, and advance the welfare of all residents of the County within it.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 17, 2011, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Western District of Texas filed this lawsuit against Nixon State Bank, a Texas-based bank.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Nixon charged higher prices for loans on the basis of national origin, including charging higher rates of interest, in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the bank failed to supervise or monitor the performance of its loan officers effectively to ensure compliance with fair lending laws.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, Nixon agreed to develop and establish uniform pricing policies and procedures to ensure that prices it charges for the loans covered by this Order, including the portion of the price that reflects the discretion of the loan officer or any company employee, are set in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with the requirements of ECOA.[SENTMARKER]Nixon also agreed to compensate its Hispanic borrowers of unsecured consumer loans.

gold_sents: On September 26, 2013, the United States of America filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District of Wisconsin against Southport Bank, under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice, sought a declaratory judgment, injunctive relief, compensatory damages to all of the victims of the defendant's discriminatory policies, and a civil penalty, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African American and Hispanic borrowers because of race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]On October 11, 2013, the District Court (Judge Joseph Peter Stadtmueller) entered a consent order between the parties.[SENTMARKER]The defendant did not admit to any pattern or practice of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The order enjoined the defendant from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race or national origin in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction in violation of the Fair Housing Act or any credit transaction in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act. pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Department of Justice brought this action against Southport Bank of Kenosha, Wisconsin, alleging that the bank discriminated against African-American and Hispanic borrowers in its residential mortgage lending program.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Southport charged hundreds of African-Americans and Hispanic wholesale borrowers higher broker fees than non-Hispanic white borrowers, not as a result of their creditworthiness or other objective criteria related to borrower risk, but because of their race and national origin.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, Southport's business practice was to allow its mortgage brokers to vary their fees and thus alter the price set based on a borrower’s objective credit-related factors.[SENTMARKER]In September 2008, the bank began to wind down its mortgage lending activities and after November of that year made virtually no new home mortgage loans.[SENTMARKER]On December 31, 2008, Southport closed ComCor.[SENTMARKER]Southport was required to collect, maintain, and report data with respect to certain loan terms and borrower information for residential loans.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice.

gold_sents: Two San Francisco Bay Area fathers filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after being detained for over 6 months in ICE custody without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction and class certification ordering that individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. § 1231(a)(6) pending a determination as to whether they can remain in the United States with “live claims”  before an adjudicative body cannot be detained for more than 180 days without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed both orders to the Ninth Circuit, and on April 7, 2020, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's order.[SENTMARKER]Following plaintiffs' motion to enforce the preliminary injunction, the court granted it in part, finding that the defendants had not substantially complied with certain requirements, but denied it in part.[SENTMARKER]As of April 16, 2021, this case is pending a writ of certiorari in front of the Supreme Court.

gold_sents: A group of Iranian refugees and their U.S. sponsors filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) denied their refugee resettlement applications en masse in February 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs applied for refugee resettlement through the Vienna, Austria-based Lautenberg-Specter program for Iranian religious minorities, but received mass denials with the sole explanation that they were denied "as a matter of discretion."[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Lautenberg Amendment, which mandates that the denial state "to the maximum extent feasible, the reason for the denial," as well as Fifth Amendment due process and DHS's own regulations.[SENTMARKER]On July 2018, the court declared the denial notices unlawful, and ordered DHS to re-issue new notices.[SENTMARKER]As of June 3, 2020, the case is still ongoing.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2020, the University of California, Riverside (UCR) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against the Department of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and the California Department of Public Health (CDPH) seeking a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICE and CDPH had violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by requiring UCR to comply with the COVID-19 pandemic response plan, which required that all classes in the Fall quarter would continue to be available in remote formats at least through the fall quarter, and that any class that was approved to be offered in person would be able to accommodate students who could not attend on-campus courses.[SENTMARKER]On July 8, 2020, there were 856 new cases of COVID19 in Riverside, as compared to two new cases on March 13, 2020, when the March 13 Guidance was issued.[SENTMARKER]On June 17, 2020, UCR announced its decision to continue remote instruction through summer 2020, and on July 6, 2020 ICE issued a broadcast message: "COVID-19 and Fall 2020" ("July 6 Directive").[SENTMARKER]The July 6 Directive largely withdraws the exception that ICE announced in March.[SENTMARKER]UCR continued to monitor and comply with Riverside County Public Health Orders throughout spring and summer, and continued to offer in-person classes through fall 2020.[SENTMARKER]On July 7, 2020, the court granted the University's motion for preliminary injunctive relief.

gold_sents: 37 families detained at three ICE-managed family residential centers sued the U.S. Department of Homeland Security alleging violations of their Fifth Amendment constitutional rights, violations of the Administrative Procedure Act, and violations of the Flores Settlement Agreement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the congregate environment and unsanitary conditions of the detention centers make them a tinderbox for a COVID-19 outbreak.[SENTMARKER]They sought immediate release until proper protocols could be implemented.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order which was granted in part and denied in part on March 30.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered ICE to provide appropriate infection protocols for the adults (a similar order from another case, Flores, applies to the children), to comply with CDC guidelines for congregate institutions, and to file a report regarding FRC capacity, implementation of the CDC guidelines, the number of detainees released, and videotape of the living conditions at the FRCs.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss and a motion in opposition to the temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the plaintiffs' later motion for a preliminary injunction demanding wholesale release of detainees on July 22.[SENTMARKER]On December 10, the court dismissed the claim under the APA and the writs of mandamus.[SENTMARKER]A hearing is scheduled for February 16, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On May 25, 2011, three foreign residents of Indiana filed a class action lawsuit against the cities of Indianapolis and Franklin and the counties of Marion and Johnson, seeking to enjoin enforcement of Indiana's Senate Enrolled Act 590, which would allow local law enforcement officers to make warrantless arrests of people who were subject to a removal order issued by an immigration court or a detainer or notice of action issued by the Department of Homeland Security, or who had been indicted or convicted of an aggravated felony, and would make the use of consular identification cards for identification within the state a civil infraction punishable by fine.[SENTMARKER]On March 28, 2013, the District Court (Judge Barker) ruled in favor of plaintiffs, granting their motion for summary judgment, and permanently enjoining defendants from enforcing Sections 18 and 20 of SEA 590.[SENTMARKER]Because plaintiffs' suit was dependent upon enforcement of these sections, the matter was dismissed without prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 25, 2011, plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana challenging the constitutionality of the recently enacted Senate Enrolled Act 590 (SEA 590), which was adopted by the Indiana General Assembly and originally scheduled to take effect on July 1, 2011.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs specifically challenged Section 201 of SEA 590, which added sections (a) to Indiana Code  35-33-1-1(1).[SENTMARKER]On June 24, 2011, our court entered a preliminary injunction in favor of Plaintiffs enjoining Defendants from enforcing Sections 18 and 20 until further order of the Court.[SENTMARKER]On December 21, 2011, City of Indianapolis filed a cross-motion for summary judgment and supporting memorandum.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2012, the Office of the Attorney General, representing the Marion and Johnson County Prosecutors, filed a response opposing Plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgement.[SENTMARKER]After careful review of the parties’ submissions, documentary evidence, and applicable legal authorities, we granted Plaintiffs’ Motion for Summary Judgment as to the State Defendants.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On June 24, 2011, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the State of Indiana and the City of Indianapolis.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the constitutionality of two sections of Indiana's Senate Enrolled Act of 2011 (SEA 590).[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs challenged Section 201 of SEA 590, which added sections (a) and (b) to Indiana Code  35-33-1-1(1). Section 201 allows warrantless arrest of a person if the officer has a removal order issued by an immigration court, a detainer or notice of action issued by the Department of Homeland Security, or probable cause to believe that the person has been indicted for or convicted of at least one aggravated felony. Section 18 makes it an infraction under Indiana law for any person other than a law enforcement officer to knowingly or intentionally offer or accept a consular identification card as a valid form of identification.[SENTMARKER]On November 20, 2011, the plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment and a supporting memorandum.[SENTMARKER]On December 21, 2011, the defendants filed a cross-motion for summary judgement.[SENTMARKER]The court granted summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.

gold_sents: Sixteen states filed this lawsuit against the federal government on September 6, 2017 in response to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) memorandum issued on Sept.[SENTMARKER]5 ending Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA).[SENTMARKER]The states sought to enjoin the federal government from carrying out portions of the DHS memorandum and from using information about DACA grantees gathered in their applications to enforce immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]While the district court granted in part the government’s motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs obtained a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2020, the Supreme Court held that DHS's decision to rescind DACA was subject to judicial review under the APA and that the rescission was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]Shortly thereafter, the Acting DHS Secretary issued a memorandum suspending DACA while DHS reviewed it.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint alleging that the Acting Secretary lacked the authority to issue the memorandum because he had not been lawfully appointed to his position.[SENTMARKER]The district court agreed.[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court vacated the memorandum and ordered DHS to resume processing DACA applications.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 6, 2017, the New York State Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the U.S. Department of Justice (D.J.)[SENTMARKER]filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York challenging the rescission of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program and DHS's alleged changes in its policy regarding the use of DACA applicants' information for immigration-enforcement purposes.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHS violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by failing to notify certain DACA grantees of the October 5, 2017 Renewal Deadline.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction and for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]In a related case, the Fifth Circuit affirmed the district court's preliminary injunction in favor of the government.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In September 2017, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) announced that it would end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which allowed certain individuals without lawful immigration status who entered the U.S. as children to obtain "deferred action" contingent, discretionary relief from deportation and authorization to work legally in this country.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New Jersey, alleging that DHS's sole stated reason for ending the DACA program was conclusory and based upon flawed legal analysis.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary nationwide injunction, and the Fifth Circuit agreed.[SENTMARKER]On September 14, 2018, the district court remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

gold_sents: In 2018, several states filed a complaint against the Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the immigration-related conditions being placed on funding disbursed by the Department of Justice violated the Separation of Powers, the APA and the Tenth Amendment Anti-Commandeering.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, a judge granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, the defendants appealed this judgment.[SENTMARKER]And later, the plaintiffs made a motion for summary judgment on the 2018 immigration-related conditions.[SENTMARKER]In February 2020, a Second Circuit panel reversed the district court's order granting partial summary judgment, vacated the mandate and injunction, and remanded the case to the district court, concluding that the Attorney General was statutorily authorized to impose the challenged conditions and that the imposition of these conditions was not arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment is currently pending before the district court.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 28, 2020, a group of New York residents filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of the United States against President Donald Trump, the Department of Commerce, and the White House.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the President's "Executive Order" that "will block" undocumented people from "receiving congressional representation" and from "being counted in the US Census" violated the Constitution and the Constitution's provisions on the counting of the "whole number of persons" for Congressional apportionment purposes, regardless of citizenship status.[SENTMARKER]On August 4, 2020, the District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctions, permanently enjoining the President from excluding undocumented immigrants from the tabulation of total population by states, and enjoining all those acting on their behalf from excluding illegal aliens from the calculation and statement of the whole number of people in each state.[SENTMARKER]The District Court's decision is not binding on this court.

pegasus_output_sents: On August 7, 2013, a group of Indian H-2B workers filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against Signal International, Inc., a Texas-based company that employed Indian workers in its labor camps.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Signal's hostile, abusive, and discriminatory treatment ofPlaintiffs and others similarly situated was unwelcome.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that they were subjected to skills testing and re-testing, on the job discipline, layoffs, periods without work, lack of safety precautions, unfavorable job assignments, evaluation processes, and other adverse employment actions to which non-Indian and United States citizen workers were not similarly subjected.[SENTMARKER]On June 17, 2015, the plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]On July 20, 2018, the Court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, finding that the defendants had violated the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) by failing to comply with the terms of the FLSA.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment also found that the plaintiffs were not entitled to any monetary relief.

gold_sents: On October 26, 2015, sixteen undocumented immigrants formerly detained in Dallas County, Texas, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Dallas County and the Dallas County Sheriff under 42 USC §1983 for violations of the Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought damages and an injunction preventing the defendants from detaining the plaintiffs solely based on a request from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), an immigration hold, or an immigration detainer.[SENTMARKER]Over time, the case was consolidated with two other lawsuits with identical claims.[SENTMARKER]The state of Texas also intervened as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]The district court initially granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, but allowed the plaintiffs to file an amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The court then dismissed the plaintiffs' due process claims, allowing them to move forward only with their Fourth Amendment claims.[SENTMARKER]By October 18, 2018, only one plaintiff was still represented by counsel and pursuing a claim (26 had dismissed their claims with prejudice, and 18 had fallen out of contact with counsel and were designated as pro se; their claims were later dismissed).[SENTMARKER]That plaintiff reached a private settlement with the defendants and the court ordered entry of the final judgment on December 4, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff was to be paid $9,500.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: This is one in a series of cases challenging comprehensive state immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]In this case, a coalition of immigrant rights groups and individual immigrants challenged Utah's law, HB 497, on preemption grounds and as a violation of equal protection, the right to travel, and the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]A preemption case brought by the Department of Justice was later consolidated with this case.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the District Court for the District of Utah has issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the statute.[SENTMARKER]Following the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. gold_sents: In 2018, Migrant Justice and four individual members of the organization filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implemented retaliatory policies in response to their activism on behalf of immigrant farm workers, including extensive surveillance and false imprisonment, in violation of their First Amendment Rights and that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) aided these practices by consistently and intentionally sharing personally identifying information about the plaintiffs with ICE in a manner that violated their Fourteenth Amendment Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the plaintiffs and the DMV settled, and the DMV agreed to implement new protocols to protect against disclosing immigration and citizenship information with ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then settled with the remaining defendants on October 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included $100,000 in damages, deferred action for the plaintiffs so they would not be deported, and ICE informing its employees that all immigrants are protected by the First Amendment.

gold_sents: This was a class-action lawsuit in which the plaintiffs alleged that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts had failed to provide medically necessary services as required under the federal Medicaid Act, and that it had failed to inform parents and children that they were entitled to these covered services.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Commonwealth violated provisions of the federal Medicaid Act by failing to provide home-based services to thousands of children across the state.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the district court approved a remedial plan intended to restructure the children’s mental health system by incorporating intensive home-based services, including behavioral health screenings, assessments, case management, crisis intervention and in-home therapeutic supports.[SENTMARKER]It also appointed a monitor to oversee implementation and compliance.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to extend the monitor’s appointment several times, with the final extension expiring on December 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to again extend the monitor’s appointment; the First Circuit overturned this ruling on May 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the extension is before the district court on remand.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 26, 2005, a group of Massachusetts residents filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts, alleging that the Massachusetts Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) violated the federal Medicaid statute by failing to comply with the "reasonable promptness" provision of the Medicaid statute.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the action on three grounds.[SENTMARKER]First, they claimed that the Commonwealth's sovereign immunity, in the Eleventh Amendment of the United States Constitution, bars the suit.[SENTMARKER]Second, they argued that the dispute was not calculated to, and did not, lead to any tangible betterment for the Plaintiff class.[SENTMARKER]Third, the defendants argued that no court-ordered relief was issued following the hearing.[SENTMARKER]The district court issued a final judgment in the form of an injunction, largely adopting the Commonwealth’s proposed remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]Fourth, the defendant appealed, and the First Circuit affirmed, holding that the defendants had failed to demonstrate substantial compliance with the decree.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On January 9, 2002, a class of Medicaid-eligible children suffering from serious emotional disturbances brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Massachusetts Department of Health and Human Services had violated the Medicaid statute by failing to provide adequate assessments and the timely provision of medically necessary intensive home-based services to which the plaintiffs were entitled under the Medicaid Act.[SENTMARKER]The court held that the defendants had failed to demonstrate substantial compliance with the judgment by the deadline originally set forth in the judgment.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed, and the First Circuit affirmed, holding that the Commonwealth's failure to achieve substantial compliance was not a safe-harbor figure.

pegasus_output_sents: On August 18, 2008, the California Association of Health Facilities filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California.[SENTMARKER]The Providers alleged that the State’s implementation of Welfare and Institutions Code  14105.191(f), which limited reimbursement rates under California’s Medicaid program, violated federal law.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Providers' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Court vacated the preliminary injunction and remanded the case to the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint status report with the Supreme Court of the United States on November 6, 2013.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On April 30, 2010, Developmental Services Network and United Cerebral Palsy/Spastic Children's Foundation of Los Angeles and Ventura Counties filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against the California Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) and the California Office of the Attorney General (OAG) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHCS had unlawfully failed to obtain federal approval of its Medicaid plan prior to implementing the state budget bill for California fiscal year 2009-2010.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for a preliminary injunction on March 28, 2011.[SENTMARKER]On June 10, 2014, the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: This lawsuit arose out of the funding provisions for elementary and secondary schools in the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) of 2020.[SENTMARKER]Filed by eight states (California, Michigan, Hawaii, Maine, Maryland, New Mexico, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin), Washington D.C., and four school districts (Chicago, Cleveland, New York City, and San Francisco), the lawsuit challenged a July 1, 2020 interim final rule from the Department of Education about how the funds may be distributed between private and public schools.[SENTMARKER]On August 26, 2020, the court granted a preliminary injunction prohibiting enforcement of the interim final rule.[SENTMARKER]On November 9, the court approved a permanent injunction that prevented the defendants from implementing the April 30 guidance and July 1 rule and from taking any action inconsistent with the proportional share formula in Section 1117 or other restrictions or penalties on the use of CARES Act funds.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction over the case for enforcement purposes.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 25, 2020, the Bureau of Children's Justice filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the Department of Education and Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos violated the Administrative Procedure Act by acting in excess of statutory authority.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the separation of powers principles, ultra vires action, and the spending clause, Article I, Section 8, Clause 11 1 of the United States Constitution, and Administrative Procedure 12 Act  706(2)(A).[SENTMARKER]On August 26, 2020, the court granted a preliminary injunction prohibiting the defendants from implementing or enforcing against the plaintiffs.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 2020, a group of states, the District of Columbia, and municipal school districts filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the United States Department of Education and the Secretary of Education.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Department's interim final rule regarding the allocation of funds under the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act of 2020 (CARES Act) violated the Constitution and the Administrative Procedure Act. On August 26, 2020, the court granted a preliminary injunction prohibiting the Department from implementing the Final Rule and the Guidance.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: In 2010, the U.S. Congress passed the Affordable Care Act (ACA) (“Obamacare”) that expanded Medicare coverage to include additional groups of beneficiaries.[SENTMARKER]Arkansas approved a work requirement in Medicaid as a requirement for health coverage in its amendments on March 5, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On August 14, 2018, three individuals filed a suit against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), as well as administrators involved in implementing the Arkansas Works Amendments (AMA) in the US District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of the SSA and the Constitution in approving the AWA in March 2018.[SENTMARKER]All three plaintiffs were beneficiaries of Medicaid who lost or risked losing medical coverage due to changes in the AWA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief against the AWA and attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]On March 27, 2019, the court held that the AWA work requirement does not advance the purpose of the SSA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment and vacated the approval for Arkansas’s program.[SENTMARKER]On April 10, 2019, the defendants appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On February 14, 2020, the Court of Appeals pegasus_output_sents: In August 2018, residents of Arkansas and Kentucky filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Secretary of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the Secretary’s approval of the Arkansas Works Amendments was arbitrary and capricious, in excess of his statutory authority, and in violation of the Take Care Clause of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The case was originally a consolidated appeal from the district court’s judgment in both states.[SENTMARKER]The parties have now come back to the Court and filed cross-motions for summary judgment in that case.[SENTMARKER]The Court issues a separate Opinion today resolving those motions, which it will refer to as Stewart II.[SENTMARKER]The only question remaining before us is whether the Secretary's authorization of Arkansas's demonstration is lawful.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 27, 2019, the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia held that the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) failed to analyze whether the Arkansas Works Amendments would promote the primary objective of Medicaid, which was to furnish medical assistance.[SENTMARKER]The case was originally a consolidated appeal from the district court’s judgment in both the Arkansas and Kentucky cases.[SENTMARKER]After oral argument, Kentucky terminated the challenged demonstration project and moved for voluntary dismissal.[SENTMARKER]The District Court entered final judgment on April 4, 2019, and the Secretary filed a notice of appeal on April 10, 2019.

gold_sents: In June 2020, the Trump Administration's Department of Health and Human Services issued a revised regulation under Section 1557 of the Affordable Care Act that limited protections for discrimination against LGBTQ individuals.[SENTMARKER]A group of LGBTQ-focused private healthcare providers, organizations providing community services, health professional associations, and individual providers filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the revised rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act, First Amendment, and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On September 2, the court found that the plaintiffs had standing for most of their claims, and enjoined the Administration from implementing two provisions: (1) the 2020 Rule's elimination of "sex stereotyping" from the 2016 Rule's definition of "discrimination on the basis of sex" and (2) the 2020 Rule's use of Title IX's exemption of certain religious organizations from the statute’s nondiscrimination mandate.[SENTMARKER]It denied relief for the 2020 Rule's elimination of the 2016 Rule’s prohibition on categorical coverage exclusions for gender-affirming care, repeal of the 2020 Rule's notice requirements, and alleged violation of Section 1554, in addition to the plaintiffs' constitutional claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2020, Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund (Lambda) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) alleging that the HHS's 2016 Final Rule on gender-affirming care violated Title IX of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the rule violated Section 1557 of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), which prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction in part and denied their motion for admission pro hac vice.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: The U.S. Department of Justice Civil Rights Division entered into this court-enforceable settlement agreement with Delaware in 2011 to remedy unconstitutional conditions in its state psychiatric hospital and to provide community-based services to prevent the unnecessary institutionalization of individuals with mental illness.[SENTMARKER]The State achieved full compliance with the agreement, and the case was closed in 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2011, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and the State of Delaware (State) filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Delaware.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the State violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide services for individuals with serious and persistent mental illness (SPMI) in its state hospitals.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which required the State to comply with the ADA and other laws that require public 56 systems to support individuals with SPMI to live successfully in their communities without being subjected to unwarranted institutional segregation.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on December 26, 2015.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division sued the State of Delaware in the U.S. District Court for the District of Delaware for violating the rights of individuals with mental illness by failing to provide reasonable, adequate mental health treatment.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the state's mental health facilities violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by denying individuals access to 24-hour access to assistance and referral information.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the state to establish a crisis hotline, provide intensive community-based services to individuals with severe mental illness (SMMI), and create a commission to monitor compliance with the agreement.

gold_sents: On January 15, 2008, a group of Medicaid-eligible adults with disabilities that were confined to a nursing-home facility filed a class action in U.S. District Court against Florida's Health Care Administration and Department of Elder Affairs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the state discriminated against them by failing to offer services that would enable them to live in a community setting.[SENTMARKER]After a bench trial, the court entered judgment for one of the named plaintiffs and decertified the class that he had previously approved.[SENTMARKER]In part because of recent legislation that greatly improved the state's efficiency at moving eligible persons from nursing homes to community living, the court determined that the conditions allowing for the class no longer existed.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2008, a group of Medicaid beneficiaries filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida, alleging that the state of Florida was unnecessarily requiring Medicaid beneficiaries to enter or remain in nursing homes in order to receive care they could and should have received in the community.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Title II of the Public Services Act of 1990 (PSA).[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss, and the plaintiffs moved to certify class of similarly situated individuals in Florida.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a preliminary injunction in favor of one named plaintiff, Clayton Griffin.[SENTMARKER]Following a bench trial, the district court dismissed as moot the claims of the other named plaintiffs, and decertified the class on the ground that it is no longer true that the case meets the requirements of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure  16(b)(2).
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On October 14, 2008, a group of Medicaid-eligible residents of nursing facilities filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Florida Agency for Health Care Administration and the Florida Department of Elder Affairs violated Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act and Section 12132 of the Rehabilitation Act by failing to provide them with services in the most integrated setting appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to decertify the class, and dismissed the claims of the other named plaintiffs as moot.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

Lebron filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against the Florida Department of Children and Families (DCF) alleging that Florida's mandatory drug-testing statute violated his Fourth Amendment right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction against the enforcement of the drug testing statute against Lebron and the State agreed to discontinue its drug testing regime as to all TANF applicants until this litigation was fully resolved.[SENTMARKER]In total, approximately 1,727 families were affected by the district court's decision.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On September 6, 2011, Florida resident Luis Lebron filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against the Florida Department of Children and Families (DCF) seeking a declaration that requiring suspicionless drug testing for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) eligibility violated his Fourth Amendment right to be free from unreasonable searches.[SENTMARKER]On October 24, 2011, the district court preliminarily enjoined the State from requiring that Lebron submit to a suspicionless drugs test pursuant to  414.0652 as a condition for receiving TANF benefits until the case was resolved.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs were a lesbian couple who filed a complaint on July 20, 2004 challenging the Federal Defense of Marriage Act, as well as Florida's implementation of the statute, as violating the Full Faith and Credit Clause, the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Privileges and Immunities Clause, and the Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution, and sought declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]On January 19, 2005, the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida held that DOMA falls within Congress' power under the Full Faith and Credit Clause, the right to same-sex marriage is not a fundamental right under the Constitution, and that DOMA passes the rational basis review test and does not violate the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]The Court dismissed the case.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs were individuals with quadriplegia who did not receive adequate in-home care services via Florida Medicaid and who were on the waitlist for the state's spinal cord injury waiver services.[SENTMARKER]After arguing that this was a violation of the ADA and Section 504, the plaintiffs received a preliminary injunction in 2010 and the state initiated waiver services soon after.[SENTMARKER]The case finally settled in 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: Two individuals with disabilities filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida, alleging that the Florida Department of Health's practice of conditioning personal attendant care services on entrance into a nursing home violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (R&A).[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, holding that the State had violated the ADA, and rejected the State’s defense that inadequate funding, rather than discrimination, was the reason for retaining the plaintiffs in an institution.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Eleventh Circuit affirmed the District Court's judgment, but remanded for a reassessment of the State's cost based defense.

pegasus_output_sents: On July 3, 2012, Disability Rights Florida, Inc. (DRF) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida against the Agency for Persons with Disabilities (APD) and the Florida Department of Elder Affairs (AHCA).[SENTMARKER]DRF alleged that APD and AHCA violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by requiring individuals on the waiting list for the Florida Medicaid Developmental Disabilities Waiver program to be confined unnecessarily in nursing facilities, rather than allow them to reside in the community in order to obtain long-term care services in violation of the ADA's integration mandate.[SENTMARKER]In October of 2011, the court denied the P&A's motion to proceed as a class action and the case proceeded instead on the basis of our agency's standing to sue and on behalf of the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In July of 2012, the case was settled.[SENTMARKER]Under the settlement agreement, DRF will be required to provide the APD with a list of individual requests for services, the amount requested, and whether each request was approved or denied.[SENTMARKER]APD will also track the IFS services requested, track the amounts requested, provide the data to DRF, and make changes to the statewide process more fair and equitable.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2011, a group of individuals with developmental disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida, alleging that Florida's Medicaid waiver program violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by placing individuals with similar disabilities in institutions rather than community-based services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state was violating the ADA by funding unnecessary placement of individuals in institutions at the expense of those individuals seeking services in the community, to the detriment of both groups.[SENTMARKER]The court held that the ADA requires the placement of a person with a disability in community settings rather than institutions when the State's treatment professionals have determined that community placement is appropriate, the transfer from the institution to the community is not opposed by the individual, and the placement can be reasonably accommodated, taking into account the resources available to the State and the needs of others with disabilities Id.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2009, a group of individuals with mental disabilities sued the Georgia Department of Behavioral Health and Developmental Disabilities (DBHDD) in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia for violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by denying them access to community-based mental health services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state's decision to end the SOURCE program violated Title II of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]In doing so, the Supreme Court interpreted the ADA's "integration mandate" as requiring persons with disabilities to be served in the community when the state determines that community treatment is appropriate.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the state agreed to end its use of SOURCE services for people with mental illnesses and developmental disabilities.

gold_sents: In September of 2011, one eighteen-year-old and four minor residents of Georgia with significant medical issues sued the agency responsible for administering Medicaid in Georgia.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the agency's decisions to deny or reduce hours of in-home, private nursing care violated the Medicaid act, the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]Two of the Plaintiffs settled and some of the Medicare, as well as the Fifth an Fourteenth Amendment Allegations were dismissed on summary Judgment, however, the District Court found for the Defendants on the remaining allegations.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed this decision and the Court of Appeals dismissed the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The district court also awarded attorneys' fees to the plaintiff, which was affirmed by the Court of Appeals.

gold_sents: On March 25, 2010, plaintiffs, minors with serious disabilities who were Medicaid recipients, filed this class-action lawsuit was filed in federal court against the Secretary of the Indiana Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA) and Director of the Office of Medicaid Policy and Planning of FSSA.[SENTMARKER]They all had been receiving medically necessary therapies paid for by the State's Medicaid program, administered by the FSAA, for several years.[SENTMARKER]These therapies were necessary to ensure the plaintiffs' conditions would not deteriorate and that they would not lose functional ability.[SENTMARKER]The FSSA had denied the named plaintiffs and others similarly situated continuing access to these therapies, citing two provisions of the Indiana Administrative Code.[SENTMARKER]On February 10, 2011, the Court granted summary judgment in favor of the Plaintiffs, issuing a permanent injunction preventing the Defendants and their successors from limiting or denying coverage for prescribed physical, occupational, or respiratory therapy, and/or speech pathology, for any person under 21 enrolled in the State's Medicaid program when such denial or limitation was based upon the two disputed provisions.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 25, 2010, a group of seriously disabled children filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the Indiana Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA) alleging that FSSA's refusal to provide Medicaid coverage for long-term psychiatric therapy services violated their civil rights under the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (C.R.A.).[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the FSSA refused to cover the services for more than two years, unless there was a significant change in their medical condition requiring longer therapy.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]The Sixth Circuit affirmed the district court's decision in PLEAS.[SENTMARKER]339 Fed Appx.[SENTMARKER]No. 1:10-cv-00358-JMS-TAB.
