gold_sents: On March 28, 2018, the NAACP and Prince George’s County, Maryland filed a claim against the U.S. Census Bureau and President Donald Trump for neglecting their constitutional duty to administer a fair and accurate census of the US population.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that underfunding and the flawed design of the 2020 Census might lead to undercounts of the US population in violation of the Enumeration Clause and to the detriment of minority populations, as the census count is tied to both public funding and governmental representation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs requested an injunction to require the US to develop a plan to ensure a fair and accurate count.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the claim for injunctive relief as unripe because census preparations were ongoing, but allowed the claim on underfunding to continue.[SENTMARKER]The court also allowed the plaintiffs to add two claims under the Administrative Procedure Act. On April 16, 2020, the court granted the government’s motion to dismiss; the case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2018, Prince George's County, a majority African American county in southeastern Maryland, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Census Bureau was violating the Fourteenth Amendment's "one-fifth of all other persons" clause by counting only three-fifths of the county's slave population.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the plaintiffs' claims for failure to state a claim and for lack of justiciability.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion and dismissed the case in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the plaintiffs argued that the district court erred in concluding that the plaintiffs lacked standing to challenge Congressional appropriations that were not "required by law," a precondition for claims brought under the APA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 28, 2018, the Prince George's County, Maryland NAACP filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Census Bureau, the Secretary of Commerce, and the United States.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Constitution's "actual enumeration clause" by failing to conduct an accurate count of the people.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the plaintiffs' claims, holding that they were unripe and would not be justiciable until after the 2020 Census was completed.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a renewed motion to dismiss, seeking dismissal of the APA claims, as well as the remaining limitedion of enumeration Clause claims based on the planned "methods and means" of conducting the census.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment (ECF No. 179), which seeks to exclude judicial review in the Constitution’s entirety.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On December 18, 2009 three young adult residents of Maine who were Medicaid recipients and who were diagnosed with cerebral palsy, filed a lawsuit against the Commissioner of the Maine Department of Health and Human Services in her official capacity.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Maine.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHHS had violated Title II of the ADA and other federal laws.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs alleged that the State had failed to accommodate Plaintiffs' disabilities and to provide medically necessary treatment in the most integrated setting possible, instead forcing them into nursing homes where they were functionally segregated from the outside world.[SENTMARKER]In August, 2010, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint reframing the case as a class action on behalf of all similarly situated Maine residents.[SENTMARKER]The parties began settlement discussions shortly thereafter.[SENTMARKER]On May 2, 2012, the Court (Judge Nancy Torresen) approved the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the State to establish a Medicaid Home and Community Based Waiver (HCBW) program, which would provide a limited number of qualifying class-members the opportunity to live in community-based settings.[SENTMARKER]The case is presumably closed.

gold_sents: On June 26, 2003, two separate suits were filed against the City of Oakland and the Oakland Police Department (OPD), and related defendants, in federal court.[SENTMARKER]The suits were filed in response to the OPD's actions on April 7 at a peaceful antiwar demonstration at the Port of Oakland.[SENTMARKER]The Police, without giving sufficient notice to disperse and without provocation, barraged demonstrators with a variety of "less-lethal" munitions, while blocking the main exit routes.[SENTMARKER]Police pursued demonstrators and others present when they attempted to disperse, while continuing to fire at them and intentionally strike them with motorcycles.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2003, the Court ordered that the cases be officially related and heard before the same judge.[SENTMARKER]One of the two cases, Local 10 ILWU v. City of Oakland, was filed as a class-action on behalf of all persons who attended the April 7 demonstration.[SENTMARKER]City of Oakland, was filed as a class-action on behalf of all persons who attended the April 7 demonstration.[SENTMARKER]The suit also named as plaintiffs Local 10 of the International Longshore and Warehouse Union, plus nine of its members who were "standing by" in the vicinity of the demonstration but not active participants in it.[SENTMARKER]The other suit, Coles v. City of Oakland, sought relieve for several individual demonstrators who were allegedly injured by the OPD.[SENTMARKER]City of Oakland, sought relieve for several individual demonstrators who were allegedly injured by the OPD.[SENTMARKER]In both cases, Plaintiffs sought compensatory, exemplary, and punitive damages, as well as to recover legal costs.[SENTMARKER]They also sought declaratory judgments holding the Defendants' actions to be unlawful violations of the Plaintiffs' rights under the Constitutions of the U.S. and of California and of statutory law.[SENTMARKER]They sought injunctions that among other things would prohibit the Defendants from unlawfully interference with the constitutional and statutory rights of participants in public demonstrations and protests.[SENTMARKER]On December 24, 2004, the parties entered a court-approved partial settlement addressing the Plaintiffs' claims for injunctive relief to the extent that those claims related to the Defendants' crowd control policies.[SENTMARKER]Oakland adopted a new official Crowd Control Policy that forbade the police from dispersing crowds that had not behaved illegally or that did not pose a clear and present danger of imminent violence.[SENTMARKER]It also forbade the indiscriminate use of less-lethal weapons directly against crowds, even when specific individuals in the group were violent.[SENTMARKER]The remaining issues eventually settled, with awards of damages and attorneys' fees well in excess of $1,000,000.

gold_sents: In November 1974, several individuals and groups filed a civil rights action against Chicago's mayor and police officials, claiming that they had engaged in unlawful intelligence gathering and electronic surveillance.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants had violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights, and they sought both damages and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]After the case was consolidated with a number of related cases, in August 1981, the parties entered into a consent decree settlement.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree barred the City from political spying, harassment, and investigation of certain activities protected by the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Despite the settlement, decades of litigation addressing enforcement of the decree followed.[SENTMARKER]In April 2011, the district court granted the City's motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The court's order permitted the plaintiffs to file a motion to reinstate the consent decree within 45 days if the City did not conduct an audit showing compliance with the terms of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]There was no further legal action taken by either party.

pegasus_output_sents: On August 27, 2014, a group of approximately 125 Seattle Police Department officers filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the City of Seattle and the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) alleging that the city's use of force policy violated the Second Amendment right of police officers to use firearms for the core lawful purpose of self-defense.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice because the case was not supported by the Constitution or case law.[SENTMARKER]On December 17, 2013, the district court issued an order approving the policy agreed to by the parties.[SENTMARKER]The parties worked with a court-appointed monitor to produce a Use of Force Policy that would apply to SPD officers’ use of approved department firearms while on duty.[SENTMARKER]The panel applied a two-step inquiry to determine whether there was a reasonable fit between the policy of Seattle’s important government interest in ensuring the safety of both the public and its police officers, and the right of the people to keep and bear arms, to achieve a law-enforcement objective.

professionals, challenging the same HHS Rule on behalf of themselves and their patients.[SENTMARKER]Washington and the NFPRHA parties filed preliminary injunctions on March 22, 2019, seeking to prohibit HHS from implementing the Final Rule.[SENTMARKER]Judge Bastian granted plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, enjoining the Final Rule nationwide until further order of the court.[SENTMARKER]On May 3, 2019, defendants filed a notice of appeal and motion to stay the preliminary injunction, as well as a notice of interlocutory and preliminary injunction appeal regarding plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On June 20, 2019, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals issued a three-judge panel per curiam decision granting defendant’s motion to stay pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit noted that the Final Rule was challenged in federal court in California, Oregon, and Washington (this case), and district courts in each case granted plaintiffs’ Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On July 11, 2019, the Ninth Circuit en banc court denied the motions for administrative stay of the three-judge panel’s order granting defendant’s motion to stay pending gold_sents: In 1964, a group of African American families filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant Jefferson Parish School Board had violated their rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by continuing to segregate the school system.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief, mandated desegregation of the school system, and required that the defendants use busing to speed up the integration process.[SENTMARKER]The injunction remained in place for several decades.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the School Board sought to implement a magnet school program in the hopes of boosting academics and increasing school diversity.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to supplement the desegregation plan to include the magnet school program, and the Court issued Consent Orders in 2008-2009 that enabled the School Board's plans.[SENTMARKER]However, issues arose in the following years with the School Board's implementation of the plan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants were using the Consent Orders as a pretext to conceal attempts to continue a system of racially segregated schools.[SENTMARKER]After the Consent Orders expired, the parties reached a settlement agreement and the Court declared Jefferson Parish Schools unitary in 2011.
pegasus_output_sents: Dandridge et al v. Jefferson Parish School Board, 332 F.S.upp.[SENTMARKER]590, filed this suit on July 30, 1964, in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The suit sought to desegregate the public schools of Jefferson Parish and to eliminate the vestiges of the prior dual school system.[SENTMARKER]On May 15, 2008, the court approved numerous unopposed modifications of the previously operative orders covering all phases of school district operation.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on June 30, 2011.

gold_sents: On Dec.[SENTMARKER]3, 1997, Barbara Grutter brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the University of Michigan Law School.[SENTMARKER]She claimed that, in denying her admission, the school discriminated against her on the basis of her race, and violated the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case made its way to the Supreme Court, which held that the law school's desire to obtain a "critical mass" of underrepresented minority students counted as a narrowly tailored use of race in its admissions process and was not unconstitutional.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 3, 1997, the University of Michigan Law School was sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan for violating the Equal Protection Clause and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by using race as a factor in its admissions decisions.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit held that the Law School's admissions policy was narrowly tailored to serve its compelling interest in achieving a diverse student body, and therefore its policy was valid.[SENTMARKER]On December 22, 2000, the District Court issued a judgment enjoining the law school from any consideration of the race of any applicant.[SENTMARKER]On May 14, 2002, the Regents of state university and its law school appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the Regents, and the case was closed.

gold_sents: On Oct. 14, 1997, two applicants who had been denied admission to the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the university.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by public interest counsel, claimed that the university's admissions policy treated race as a predominant factor in granting admission, and that they, as white applicants, had been discriminated against in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case went to the Supreme Court, which held that the school's admission policy that automatically awarded 20 points out of a possible 150 to underrepresented minorities was not narrowly tailored to achieve the compelling interest of diversity in education and so violated the Equal Protection Clause.

gold_sents: On April 8, 2014, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island alleging that Rhode Island violated the ADA by segregating individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities in sheltered workshops and facility-based day programs that denied them the opportunity to associate with those who did not have a disability.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2014, the District Court approved a Consent Decree where Rhode Island agreed to, among other things, provide employment planning services to individuals with developmental and intellectual disabilities designed to encourage and assist them in working in integrated working environments, provide state support and services for those working in integrated settings and those making the transition to those settings, programs to educate relevant individuals about the programs and benefits that the Rhode Island offers to those working in integrated settings.[SENTMARKER]Rhode Island must also implement policies regarding the services required by the Consent Decree, train its personnel in the new procedures and working with individuals with disabilities, and Rhode Island must help sheltered workshops change their structure to become integrated working environments.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 11, 2013, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Rhode Island Department of Education (RIDE) violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Supreme Court's decision in Olmstead v. L.C.[SENTMARKER]by failing to serve individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD) in the most integrated day activity service setting appropriate for their needs, and by placing transition-age youth at serious risk of segregation.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in September 2014 to resolve the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the State to implement a system of integrated employment and integrated day services for individuals with I/DD in the state's public schools.[SENTMARKER]The Court Monitor reported that while progress had been made by the State in addressing the provisions of the Court Order, additional steps needed to be taken to fully comply with the terms and conditions of the Consent Decree.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On April 9, 2014, the Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division, and the Rhode Island Department of Education filed this consent decree in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was designed to change the nature and operation of day and employment services furnished to individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD) who receive publicly financed supports.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the consent decree, the State made a sustained commitment to transform its service system to provide individuals with IDD the training and support they need to: (a) become employed in competitive, integrated jobs working alongside people without disabilities and paid a minimum wage or higher; and (b) fully participate in community activities of their own choosing with friends, families, and other members of society.[SENTMARKER]The plan should include requirements for effective outreach and in-reach, transition, discovery, and vocational and situational assessment for service recipients and their families.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In the mid-1980s, personal assistants in the Rehabilitation Program sought to unionize and collectively bargain with the State of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The State Labor Relations Board, however, found that the personal assistants were in a unique employment relationship and that it lacked jurisdiction over that relationship because the State was not their sole employer.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs’ claims with prejudice and noted that the plaintiffs failed to articulate any impermissible way in which the statutory scheme impinged upon their First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit affirmed in relevant part, concluding that the case was controlled by the Supreme Court’s decision in Abood v. Detroit Bd.[SENTMARKER]of Educ.[SENTMARKER]The Court held that a government entity may, consistently with the First Amendment, require public employees to pay a fair share of the cost that a union incurs negotiating on their behalf for better terms of employment.

gold_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles brought this suit against the U.S. Attorney General and  Secretary of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs challenged the federal immigration rule restricting eligibility for asylum for noncitizens who transited through another country prior to reaching the southern U.S. border.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs successfully sought a preliminary nationwide injunction.[SENTMARKER]However, defendants appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit and the nationwide scope of the injunction was stayed.[SENTMARKER]Then the District Court restored the nationwide scope of the injunction on September 9, 2019, but the government again appealed and the U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay pending disposition of the appeal in the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued a separate preliminary injunction against another rule issued by the Department of Homeland Security in the closing days of the Trump Administration which was substantially similar to the one already enjoined.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the original injunction in April, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing but is likely to terminate soon given the change in presidential administrations.

gold_sents: On January 20, 2010, an employee of the federal judiciary married to her same-sex partner under California law filed a lawsuit against the federal Office of Personnel Management (OPM) in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, San Francisco Division, alleging that the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) violates the Fifth Amendment by refusing to recognize lawful same-sex marriages for purposes of the laws governing spousal health benefits for federal employees, thereby denying her of a benefit that would be available to her if her spouse were of the opposite sex.[SENTMARKER]On February 22, 2012, the District Court granted summary judgment to the plaintiff, holding that the application of DOMA to deny spousal health benefits in this case did not have a rational basis and thus constituted a Fifth Amendment violation.[SENTMARKER]It entered a permanent injunction prohibiting the defendants from interfering with the enrollment of the plaintiff's wife in her family health benefits plan.[SENTMARKER]On July 3, 2012, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a petition in the Supreme Court for certiorari prior to judgment.[SENTMARKER]That petition was held without decision while the Court considered the California Prop.[SENTMARKER]8 case (PB-CA-0029 in this Clearinghouse) and Windsor, the DOMA case from the Second Circuit (PB-NY-0017 in this Clearinghouse), in which the Court granted review on December 7.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed following the decision in Windsor holding § 3 of DOMA unconstitutional.

pegasus_output_sents: A married couple filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina against the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief for the violation of their rights under the Fourteenth Amendment to equal protection under the law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHEC's refusal to issue accurate birth certificates for the children of same-sex spouses on the same terms as children of different-sEX spouses is unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires DHEC to issue two-parent birth certificates to married, non-genetic parents of children born in the state, and to use the same protocols and procedures as those used for married, different-Sex parents.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On June 12, 2018, Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund Inc. filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina against the Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) in the United States District Court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHEC's refusal to issue birth certificates to same-sex spouses on the same terms as it applies to opposite-sEX spouses violated their Fourteenth Amendment rights to equal treatment and due process.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which DHEC agreed to change its birth certificate policies and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires that the birth mother will be listed on the original birth record as the "Mother" of a child born in the state.[SENTMARKER]The birth certificate will be provided free of charge to the general public.

gold_sents: A deaf prison inmate who primarily communicates in American Sign Language filed a lawsuit under the Americans with Disabilities Act against the Oregon Department of Corrections, claiming they failed to communicate with him for over 14 years.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit claimed that, instead of providing interpreters, the prison made him train other inmates as his interpreters and they were not qualified to help him and were also privy to confidential information.[SENTMARKER]In May 2016, the Court granted partial summary judgment for the defendant.[SENTMARKER]Following a jury trial on the remaining claims, the Court dismissed the plaintiff's ADA claim for failure to exhaust administrative remedies under the PLRA.[SENTMARKER]The jury awarded the plaintiff $400,000 in noneconomic damages.[SENTMARKER]The Court awarded the plaintiff $683,873.13 in attorneys' fees, $18,155.19 in costs, and $3,924.79 in litigation expenses.[SENTMARKER]Although both parties appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, they agreed to voluntarily dismiss their appeals in September 2017.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 22, 2014, an inmate at the Oregon Department of Corrections filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that the defendant failed to provide him with an interpreter of any kind and did not engage in effective communication with him during the intake interviews or new inmate orientation at SCI.[SENTMARKER]He also alleged that he was excluded from meaningful participation in religious services and that his safety was placed at risk by having to use the inmate interpreters for confidential settings.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the inmate's motion for summary judgment and ordered the defendant to pay $460,000 to the inmate.

gold_sents: On November 10, 2011, the plaintiff--an Oregon Department of Corrections inmate-- filed this lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, in U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the Oregon Department of Corrections violated his First Amendment free speech rights, his Fourteenth Amendment Due Process rights, and his Eighth Amendment right to be free of cruel and unusual punishment, when they rejected a return a letter written to another ODOC inmate because the envelope had a drawing on it.[SENTMARKER]On May 14, 2015, the District Court enjoined the challenged prison policy.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 10, 2011, an inmate at the Oregon State Penitentiary filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon against the Oregon Department of Corrections (ODOC) and the New Mexico Corrections Department (NMCD) alleging that the defendants violated his First Amendment free speech rights and his Fourteenth Amendment due process rights when they rejected his mail containing a drawing on the front of the envelope.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for summary judgment on all of Plaintiff's claims.[SENTMARKER]On November 14, 2013, the Court granted the defendants qualified immunity insofar as Plaintiff sought money damages.[SENTMARKER]On February 19, 2015, the Court issued a declaratory and injunctive injunction against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The Court found that ODOC's policy of rejecting inmate mail for containing artwork on the back of the envelopes constituted a direct violation of the plaintiff's First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the defendants to provide the recipient with a notice in the ODOC newsletter that is issued to inmates on a routine basis.

gold_sents: The Disability Rights Network (DRN), a Pennsylvania non-profit, filed this Eighth Amendment suit against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (PDOC) for the PDOC's use of solitary confinement with severely mentally ill prisoners.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2015, the parties executed a settlement agreement for dismissal of the matter, in which the PDOC agreed to implement certain improvements and to pay $750,000 to DRN.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the PDOC will evaluate all incoming prisoners for serious mental illness, and will place prisoners with serious mental illness in solitary confinement only in "exceptional" circumstances; even then, a prisoner with serious mental illness can be kept in solitary confinement for no longer than 30 days and must be allowed out of their cells for 20 hours per week.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also provided for a monitor to report on compliance, and will remain in effect for 3 years (less if the defendant demonstrates substantial compliance for a period of 18 months).[SENTMARKER]There has been no activity on the docket since May 2015 and the case is presumably closed since the three year time period set in the agreement has lapsed.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 11, 2013, the Disability Rights Network of Pennsylvania and the American Civil Liberties Union of Pennsylvania filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (DOC).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DOC's solitary confinement of prisoners with mental illness violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The ADA requires that prisoners with serious mental illness be placed in solitary confinement for at least 30 days, and every 90 days if confinement continues, in practice any such assessment recommending the removal of a mentally ill prisoner from the RHU is ignored.[SENTMARKER]On January 15, 2015, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the ADA and Rehabilitation Act violations would be resolved by the end of 2015 and that there would be no further litigation.

pegasus_output_sents: In May 2013, a prisoner in the State Correctional Institution at Mahanoy (SCI Mahanoy), Greene (SCI Greene) and Dallas (SCI Dallas) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA) against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (PDOC) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, including placement in general population, as well as compensatory and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the conditions of his incarceration in solitary confinement almost totally deprive him of human contact, physical activity, personal property, mental stimulation, and mental stimulation.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a Motion to Dismiss, with brief in support, in which they sought to have Plaintiff’s claims dismissed with prejudice pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).[SENTMARKER]On April 14, 2016, the Justice Department announced that it had closed its investigation into the use of solitary confinement on prisoners with serious mental illness and intellectual disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The department's investigation was conducted by attorneys with the Special Litigation Section of the Office of the United States Attorney's Office for the Pennsylvania District Office.[SENTMARKER]The investigation found a pattern of constitutional violations and violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) at SCI Mahanoy, Greene, and Dallas.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: A prisoner filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections, alleging that he was deprived of his Eighth Amendment rights under the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by being placed in solitary confinement in the SCI-Mahanoy on Restricted Release List (RRL) status.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that his prolonged solitary confinement deprived him of social interaction, environmental stimulation, and mental health.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, finding that the Defendant's policies and procedures for placement of inmates in administrative segregation in Pennsylvania state prisons were in compliance with the requirements of minimal due process required in the prison environment.

pegasus_output_sents: In 2014, current and former residents of the Alexander County Housing Authority (ACHA) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that ACHA and its agents discriminated against residents of its McBride and Elmwood family housing developments based on their race and familial status, in violation of the Fair Housing Act, Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the Illinois Civil rights Act of 2003.[SENTMARKER]ACHA also overcharged its residents for rent, in many instances collecting $100-$200 per month in excess of the limit permitted by federal law.[SENTMARKER]ACHA has refused to place families with children in certain public housing developments, such as Connell Smith, in order to prevent African American families from living in majority white public housing.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in 2014 with a consent decree that required ACHA to comply with the terms of the consent decree and to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of compensatory damages, abatement of rent, punitive damages, and prejudgment interest.

gold_sents: Individuals issued summonses by the NYPD without probable cause brought a class action suit against the City of New York.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the NYPD's 'quota' policy is linked to officer promotion and demotion, and as a result, leads to commanding officers ordering police officers to arrest and issue summonses to individuals without probable cause, in contravention of the federal and state constitutions.[SENTMARKER]Judge Sweet, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, granted the case class action status in April 2012.[SENTMARKER]On January 24, 2017, Judge Sweet preliminary approved the parties' settlement agreement, in which the parties agreed to settlement benefits of up to seventy-five million dollars.[SENTMARKER]On April 18, 2017, the court granted final approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing for compliance purposes.

gold_sents: In July 2008, the plaintiffs sued the City of Tenaha under the Fourth Amendment (unreasonable search and seizure) and the Fourteenth Amendment (equal protection).[SENTMARKER]They claimed that law enforcement officials in and around the City of Tenaha have developed an illegal practice of targeting, stopping, detaining, searching, and often seizing property from people who appeared to be non-white or who were traveling with non-white passengers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that they had been victims of such stops and seizures of amounts up to $50,000, as well as false prosecution or detention.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement in August 2012.[SENTMARKER]Their proposed consent decree included: video and audio recordings of all stops; written documentation with details of the stop; no more dog searches in routine traffic stops; written and oral consent for a search; all asset forfeiture revenue must be donated to nonprofits or used for audio/video equipment or training; and use of an impartial monitor.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree, which it later extended to early 2021 after the plaintiffs alleged noncompliance by the City.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas against the City of Tenaha Deputy City Marshal Barry Washington and Shelby County Constables Zack Warr, Shad Sparks, and Chad Carlton Rook.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the civil rights of African Americans by conducting traffic stops and searches that resulted in the arrest and detention of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a consent decree in August 2013 that required the defendants to adopt an impartial policing policy, provide written notice to any person before a canine sniff is used at a traffic stop and before seeking consent to conduct a search, make audio and video recordings of all traffic stops, all searches, seizures, detentions, and arrests, and provide written inventory of all property seized.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then sought a discretionary appeal of the class certification pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(f) which was denied, and then denied again when the defendants asked the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals to rehear the request.[SENTMARKER]On December 13, 2018, the parties filed a Proposed Settlement Agreement on Additional Duration of Consent Decree which was approved and ordered by the Court on August 8, 2013 (Doc.[SENTMARKER]261-1 through -7) and extended the duration of the consent decree to four years from the date of entry of this consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On or before 20 days from the posting of this notice, any plaintiff class member wishing to comment or object to the proposed settlement must do so in writing, referencing the name and number of this case as listed above, and filed with the court.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In August 2012, the ACLU of Texas filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas against the City of Tenaha, Shelby County District Attorney's Office, and the Tenaha Police Department.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants targeted non-white citizens and those traveling with non-White citizens by detaining, searching, and often seizing their property during traffic stops.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied these allegations.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in August 2012 via a proposed consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the defendants to adopt an impartial policing policy, use mechanical recording equipment for traffic stops, maintain the recordings of such stops for four years, and donate any asset forfeiture revenue seized during a traffic stop to non-profit organizations or training required by the settlement.

gold_sents: This case was filed in response to the July 6, 2020 directive by ICE that would effectively force international students studying under F-1 and M-1 visas to attend in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The state of California filed this suit against ICE and DHS on July 9, arguing that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) in two ways.[SENTMARKER]First, the directive was arbitrary and capricious in that it failed to take into account students' and universities' reliance interests and the defendants gave no reasoned basis for the new order.[SENTMARKER]Second, the defendants were in violation of procedural elements of the APA, because they failed to use proper notice-and-comment rule-making when issuing the new order.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]California continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 19, 2020.

gold_sents: On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents separated from their children filed a civil action against various federal agencies and officials in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for immediate reunification with their children.The plaintiffs were detained after crossing the United States-Mexico border without inspection with young accompanying children, seeking asylum.[SENTMARKER]After plaintiffs were apprehended at the border, the children were separated under the “zero-tolerance” immigration policy announced April 6, 2018, which criminally prosecuted adult entrants crossing the border illegally and placed accompanying minors in custody of the government.[SENTMARKER]All three plaintiffs crossed the border prior to the Executive Order issued on June 20, 2018, which allowed immigrant parents and children apprehended at the border to remain together during the pendency of their proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged interference of family integrity in violation of Due Process, and sought preliminary and permanent injunctions to immediately reunite plaintiffs with their children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs obtained preliminary relief and were (along with another parent who joined the case later to prevent separation from her daughter) ultimately re-united with their children.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 2, 2011, two companies filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the government's National Security Letter (NSL) gag order violated their First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The NSL prohibited the companies from disclosing information about the NSL or its petition to the affected customer, to most of Appellee's employees and staff, to the press, to members of the public, and to Congress.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the government’s motion to enforce.[SENTMARKER]On June 3, 2011, the parties appealed the district court's denial of their petitions to set aside the nondisclosure requirement in the 2011 and 2012 NSLs.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the District Court to address the first amendment issues presented in the revised statute.

gold_sents: This class action was about whether the City of New York improperly denied federally sponsored cash assistance to qualified New York City residents under a program implemented by the city in the late 1990s.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs each claimed to be qualified welfare beneficiaries who had been improperly denied assistance by one of New York City’s new job centers in violation of the fourteenth amendment guarantee of due process, the city’s obligations under 7 U.S.C. §2020 (the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program—then referred to as Food Stamps) and 42 U.S.C. §1396 (Medicaid), in addition to violating state law; the plaintiffs sought class certification for all similarly situated New York City residents, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on December 16, 1998, with Judge William H. Pauley presiding.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a temporary restraining order on the same day directing the city to provide emergency food stamps and cash assistance to the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in-part to the plaintiffs on January 21, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the city to (1) allow applicants for public assistance to apply for benefits the first day they visit a job center, (2) cease conversion of income support centers to job centers without a formal hearing, (3) make eligibility requirements for food stamps and Medicaid separately from the eligibility determination from cash assistance, (4) send applicants timely notice of the city’s decision on whether they qualify for benefits, and (5) form a corrective plan for achieving its policy goals while also meeting the needs of public assistance applicants.[SENTMARKER]The city moved to vacate the preliminary injunction on December 10, 1999, after procuring more evidence surrounding the efficacy of the job centers in achieving their welfare obligations.[SENTMARKER]Meanwhile, the State of New York moved to dismiss the complaint against them for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]Judge Pauley denied both motions and granted the plaintiff’s motion for class certification on July 21, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on December 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction directed both the city and state to: (i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applications within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](iii) send notices to applicants confirming voluntary withdrawals for Medicaid in accord with 42 C.F.R. 435.913 and document such withdrawals pursuant to 7 C.F.R. 273.2(c)(6); and (iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing certain documentation.[SENTMARKER]The injunction also required the state to supervise the city and make sure it met the obligations of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the part of the December order in which the court concluded that 8 N.Y.C.R.R.[SENTMARKER]§ 387.8(a)(2)(i)(a) did not confer a privately enforceable right of action and that plaintiffs’ claim under New York Social Services Law § 133 was barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion on February 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Final judgement was entered on December 14, 2005; the court also granted the plaintiffs declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Both the state and the city appealed the permanent injunction to the Second Circuit on January 12, 2006, but the city dropped its appeal.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, the Second Circuit reversed the district court, ruling that the state did not have a non-delegable duty to administer the decentralized Medicaid and Food Stamp programs, the state’s efforts in supervising the city since the permanent injunction was issued were adequate, and the district court exceeded its authority by issuing a permanent injunction in light of New York State’s affirmative supervisory steps it had taken to assure compliance.[SENTMARKER]In a series of stipulations and orders from January 31, 2007 to July 22, 2011, the City of New York agreed to pay a total of $2,920,675.94 to plaintiffs for attorney fees and costs sought; the state agreed to pay a further $639,918.98.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, two Missouri Medicaid recipients filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri after being denied medication to treat their Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Missouri Department of Social Services and MO HealthNet denied medically necessary treatment to Medicaid beneficiaries with Hepatitis C, discriminated against similarly situated Medicaid beneficiaries, failed to provide "reasonably prompt" treatment, violated due process, and violated the American with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]In November 2017, MO HealthNet modified its policies and the case was dismissed as moot without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in November 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2017, a group of Medicaid recipients with Hepatitis C virus (HCV) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri against the Missouri Department of Social Services (DSS) and the Director of the MO HealthNet Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DSS's policies and prior authorization criteria exclude them from medically necessary, direct-acting antiviral (DAA) treatment while providing the same treatment to other Medicaid enrollees with HCV.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction prohibiting DSS from requiring three months of negative drug and alcohol screens prior to submitting requests for DAA approval.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: This case was filed on behalf of enrollees in the Missouri Medicaid program, also known as MO HealthNet, who are infected with the Hepatitis C virus (HCV), a serious and communicable disease that can cause severe liver scarring, liver damage, cancer, and death.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs allege that the Missouri Department of Social Services' arbitrary and improper policies restrict treatment for medically necessary treatment only to the sickest beneficiaries.[SENTMARKER]Without this treatment, damage to enrollees’ livers grows more severe and the risk of complications increases.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 5, 2017, a transgender woman incarcerated in the Washington State Department of Corrections filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, Nonnie Lotusflower, filed a motion for partial summary judgment, arguing that defendants’ gender dysphoria policy is unconstitutional on its face 1 because it was a blanket ban on gender confirmation surgery, precluding surgery without any consideration for medical necessity.[SENTMARKER]The parties recently executed a settlement agreement, under which Ms. Lotusflower will receive the medical treatment she 2 seeks if a professional evaluator determines that she is ready for surgery and that it is medically necessary.[SENTMARKER]After the terms of the settlement have been satisfied, the parties will file a stipulated motion to dismiss this action with prejudice.

gold_sents: The NAACP and Detroit students and parents sued the Detroit school board and other state defendants in federal court, alleging unconstitutional segregation in Detroit's schools.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that Detroit's schools were illegally segregated, in part because of decisions made by the school board to create and maintain and segregated system.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that a Detroit-only remedy would be insufficient, and ordered a busing plan that would have affected students in city schools and 53 largely white suburban school districts, but the Supreme Court rejected this plan and a Detroit-only remedy was implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 3, 1970, a class of Detroit school children filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan alleging that the Detroit School District was segregated on the basis of race.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that certain conduct on the part of the defendant Detroit Board of Education and the defendant State of Michigan, through its various state officials, fostered segregation in the Detroit Public School System and violated the Fourteenth Amendment rights of Detroit children.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court for an expedited trial on the merits.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Sixth Circuit held that portions of Act 48 were unconstitutional and at the same time ordered that the Governor and Attorney General remain as parties to the litigation.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed in part.
